newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Goldman Sachs forecasts NZ dlr slide to US$0.62.
newsitem.headline: Goldman Sachs forecasts NZ dlr slide to US$0.62.

text.p: New York-based investment bank Goldman Sachs expects the kiwi dollar to slip to 62 U.S. cents over the next six months, the New Zealand Press Association reported on Wednesday.
Goldman Sachs forecast the kiwi at 64 cents three months out, falling to 62 cents six-months out, and returning to 64 cents one-year out.
The kiwi was trading at 65.0 U.S. cents on Wednesday morning.
"In the near term, some support seems available around the 64 cent area but we would look to sell or stay short for a target of 62," the bank said in its Weekly Analyst newsletter.
Goldman Sachs has consistently viewed the New Zealand dollar as over-valued in recent years.
It said it had revised its forecasts on the deterioration in business sentiment reported in the New Zealand Institute of Economic Research quarterly survey of business opinion.

While the recent sell-off in the kiwi, in line with the Reserve Bank's monetary conditions index (MCI), had led to a sharp rise in short-term interest rates, Goldman Sachs said that was unlikely to support the kiwi.
"The market will believe these rates are not sustainable," it said.

"Indeed, in the next few weeks the markets will look ahead to the September monetary policy statement in anticipation of a further additional easing in the MCI profile over the next six to nine months.
"We now see the kiwi dropping to 62 U.S. cents in the next six months as the RBNZ shifts to a policy of containing the economy's weakness."
